Thompson, which is spelled T-H-O-M-P-S-O-N.
Amanda, you've got a long and venerable history in helping the Carnival come about.
Would you care to tell us about your initial involvement and that which happened thereafter?
Yes, I came to work for Swicker initially part-time and I started in 1995.
And I worked as an assistant to Steve for nine years until 2003.
So I saw quite a few different manifestations of the Cardiff Carnival over that time.
And various different people who worked on it.
And every year an increase in the number of people that took part in it.
Are there any costumes that stick in your mind in particular?
I have to say, as the co-organiser with myself, we weren't able to wear costumes because the police never recognised us as the organisers.
But in our picture archive there will certainly be the classic picture of you as, I like to call you Miss Wales, a giant backpack costume.
That's right.
In red, white and green, holding two white flags as well.
That's right. That was in 2005.

Yeah.

Yeah, that was a great opportunity to wear a great big backpack costume, which I think I've always wanted to have done that.
I'm glad I got a chance to do that.
You did actually let me take part in the carnival in the first year when I joined in 1995.
Oh, excellent. What were you doing in the first one?

And that's why people should take part.

That's right. Yeah.

It was a golden age. It wasn't that staged either.
I mean, we did prepare to a certain extent, but a lot of it just kind of happened spontaneously.
We were lucky because very little ever really went wrong.

But now you have, of course, a lot more staged performances, but you also spread it out a lot more.
I think a lot more people get to see it now.
You just have to change with the times, really.
But I think every year we did it. You know, the standard changed.

Yes. And that was announced and that was canceled.

And I suppose if we're going to tell the story in full, it was the first time we've ever tried to remount a carnival parade.
And whilst we've had hundreds of enthusiastic carnivalists and community participants in the original parade,
we had formed a contract with Cardiff Bay Development Corporation,
which we then used the money to actually fund the original parade on the basis that hundreds of these people would come back and do it all again.
I can recall you and I being there and being somewhat bemused and then horrified by the low turnout.

Football matches, everything.

Well, perhaps all the other Cardiff carnivals might not have happened.
